image.altText: A Caucasian woman with brown hair, wearing glasses and a blazer.

items.synopsis: The next RBA governor is announced after a morning cabinet meeting, following the confirmation that the current governor, Philip Lowe, would not have his term renewed. Follow live.

title.children: 'History-making': PM and treasurer announce Michele Bullock as new RBA governor

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Was Lowe really paid close to $1 million? Will Bullock get the same? Seems the RBA have brought nothing but misery. - Josh. Hi Josh, thanks for your question. Yes, Philip Lowe was receiving around $1 million in year as RBA governor. The RBA's annual report in 2022 showed Mr Lowe had a base salary of $890,252 a year. He also received $115,171 in superannuation contributions. On top of other benefits, he earned a total of $1,037,709 in the 2021-22 financial year. Given Ms Bullock's wealth of experience, which is very similar to Mr Lowe's, we can expect her to be receiving a similar amount when she takes over in September.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will Michele Bullock be paid the same as Philip Lowe?

children.content: Was Lowe really paid close to $1 million? Will Bullock get the same? Seems the RBA have brought nothing but misery.
- Josh
Hi Josh, thanks for your question.
Yes, Philip Lowe was receiving around $1 million in year as RBA governor.
The RBA's annual report in 2022 showed Mr Lowe had a
base salary of $890,252 a year
He also received
$115,171 in superannuation contributions.
On top of other benefits, he earned a total of
$1,037,709 in the 2021-22 financial year
Given Ms Bullock's wealth of experience, which is very similar to Mr Lowe's, we can expect her to be receiving a similar amount when she takes over in September.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I've met Michele Bullock a few times in person and have covered several of her speeches but, from my limited exposure, she seems very intelligent (as you'd expect of a senior RBA official with a masters degree from the London School of Economics). My impression is that she is a more natural communicator than Philip Lowe, who always came across as slightly awkward in public appearances, even though he was very willing to engage with the media, including through informal one-on-one conversations and appearing at the Walkley business journalism lunch and National Press Club events. My colleague Peter Ryan has a similar impression of Bullock from his interactions with her: "In my experience, Michele Bullock is approachable, a top communicator and committed to driving the economy in the right direction. "I recall several years ago when the RBA released a research paper on the declining use of cash, I requested a briefing from the authors expecting no one would be available. "Instead Ms Bullock got back to me on the phone and agreed to come to the ABC studios to be interviewed the next morning on AM — not arriving in a Commonwealth car with fanfare but in a regular tax with her laptop in a backpack." Bullock's speaking skills will be tested as the bank faces increased transparency after previous communications missteps, with a press conference to follow every board meeting starting next year. However, it's clear that her appointment is "steady as she goes" and is unlikely to mark a radical departure from Lowe's tenure. More from Peter Ryan : "Michele Bullock is known to be close to Philip Lowe and long-regarded as a protégé. Effectively Ms Bullock has been 'a heartbeat away' from the top role for some time and known to be one of Philip Lowe's key confidantes. "In essence, Ms Bullock mirrors Philip Lowe to a large extent. "Like Mr Lowe's she's an inflation hawk and recently provided a reality check stating the unemployment rate might need to rise to 4.5 per cent by the end of the year to get inflation back towards the 2 to 3 per cent target. "Importantly, this appointment provides certainty locally and also globally that an RBA veteran is at the control to implement the recommendations from the Reserve Bank Review, many of which will be difficult." Another thing that Bullock has in common with Lowe is that they're both country NSW kids who ended up as RBA "lifers", ultimately making it to the top in Australia's financial capital at the central bank's HQ in Martin Place, Sydney.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is Michele Bullock like? Who will we be getting as RBA governor?

children.content: I've met Michele Bullock a few times in person and have covered several of her speeches but, from my limited exposure, she seems very intelligent (as you'd expect of a senior RBA official with a masters degree from the London School of Economics).
My impression is that she is
a more natural communicator than Philip Lowe

, who always came across as slightly awkward in public appearances, even though he was very willing to engage with the media, including through informal one-on-one conversations and appearing at the Walkley business journalism lunch and National Press Club events.
My colleague
Peter Ryan
has a similar impression of Bullock from his interactions with her:
"In my experience, Michele Bullock is approachable, a top communicator and committed to driving the economy in the right direction.
"I recall several years ago when the RBA released a research paper on the declining use of cash, I requested a briefing from the authors expecting no one would be available.

"Instead Ms Bullock got back to me on the phone and agreed to come to the ABC studios to be interviewed the next morning on AM — not arriving in a Commonwealth car with fanfare but in a regular tax with her laptop in a backpack."
Bullock's speaking skills will be tested as the bank faces increased transparency after previous communications missteps, with
a press conference to follow every board meeting starting next year
However, it's clear that her appointment is "steady as she goes" and is
unlikely to mark a radical departure from Lowe's tenure
More from
Peter Ryan

"Michele Bullock is known to be close to Philip Lowe and long-regarded as a protégé. Effectively Ms Bullock has been 'a heartbeat away' from the top role for some time and known to be one of Philip Lowe's key confidantes.
"In essence, Ms Bullock mirrors Philip Lowe to a large extent.

"Like Mr Lowe's she's an inflation hawk and recently provided a reality check stating the unemployment rate might need to rise to 4.5 per cent by the end of the year to get inflation back towards the 2 to 3 per cent target.

"Importantly, this appointment provides certainty locally and also globally that an RBA veteran is at the control to implement the recommendations from the Reserve Bank Review, many of which will be difficult."

Another thing that Bullock has in common with Lowe is that they're both country NSW kids who ended up as RBA "lifers", ultimately making it to the top in Australia's financial capital at the central bank's HQ in Martin Place, Sydney.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Philip Lowe became a household name since last May, after the RBA raised the cash rate to bring inflation down, much to the ire of millions of Australians — especially those with a mortgage. But with the changeover of governors in September, that doesn't mean we will magically see a change in how the RBA approaches interest rates. As deputy RBA governor, Michele Bullock has been involved in all the board meetings that have decided to increase the cash rate, and the communications we've frequently heard about how "more monetary policy tightening may be needed" (aka, more rate rises). Just on Wednesday, we heard Lowe say more rate rises might be necessary in the coming months to drive down inflation. Whether that happens before Lowe's tenure ends in September, or it happens when Bullock's begins, we will have to wait and see — and there is certainly a lot of economic data to be released and digested before that happens. (For what it's worth in the short-term, ANZ is now expecting interest rates will remain on hold at 4.1 per cent for a while longer —but this was released before Bullock's appointment was announced. You can read more about the ANZ's forecast for rates here .)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A new RBA governor doesn't necessarily mean a change to interest rates

But with the changeover of governors in September, that
doesn't mean we will magically see a change in how the RBA approaches interest rates
As deputy RBA governor,
Michele Bullock

Just on Wednesday, we heard Lowe say more rate rises might be necessary in the coming months to drive down inflation.
Whether that happens before Lowe's tenure ends in September, or it happens when Bullock's begins, we will have to wait and see — and there is certainly
a lot
of economic data to be released and digested before that happens.
(For what it's worth in the short-term, ANZ is now expecting interest rates will remain on hold at 4.1 per cent for a while longer —but this was released before Bullock's appointment was announced.

image.altText: Michele Bullock fronting a Senate estimates hearing

items.synopsis: Michele Bullock will become the first woman to lead the Reserve Bank of Australia, replacing incumbent Philip Lowe following months of speculation about the governor's future.

title.children: Michele Bullock becomes first woman to serve as RBA governor, replacing Philip Lowe

image.altText: Cassy O'Connor composite image.

items.synopsis: A tearful Cassy O'Connor had many thinking she was done with politics when she announced she was standing down as Leader of the Tasmanian Greens — in less than a minute it became clear she is just switching targets, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: 'Passionate advocate' gives up top Tasmanian Greens' job to set sights on new prize

image.altText: A hand caresses a platypus resting on a blanket.

items.synopsis: The death of a platypus found in a city suburb may reflect the fate of the entire species if we don't pay closer attention to how this Australian animal is faring.

title.children: The platypus survived megafauna and continental drift, but can it survive us?

image.altText: Peter Dutton rubs his eye.

items.synopsis: The Federal by-election for the seat of Fadden could deliver a blow or a boost for Peter Dutton next week, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: A huge hurdle is coming for Dutton — but a bigger challenge is right behind

image.altText: Smiling person, short brown hair, hands on hip, wears Australian Army uniform dress. Sunshine, blurred house, greenery behind.

items.synopsis: When Captain Jesse Noble realised they were gender diverse, it felt like being " hit in the face with a truck". A Christian marriage, their faith, and their career in the army were all at stake.

title.children: How Jesse's dress is overturning the army's gender diversity policy

image.altText: Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong speaks during meeting.

items.synopsis: The Australian foreign minister says China needs to continue to free up trade for Australian products if Anthony Albanese is to visit there later this year.

title.children: Penny Wong in frank talks with China over trade and human rights at ASEAN summit

image.altText: Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling

items.synopsis: The last time Hollywood's actors and writers went on strike at the same time, the biggest stars were fighting for residual pay cheques. Decades later, streaming giants and artificial intelligence are at the heart of the debate.

title.children: An awkward Emmys and no more Barbie red carpets: What happens next with Hollywood on strike?

image.altText: A composite image of a woman wearing a blue saree next to a Barbie doll wearing a saree

items.synopsis: Sixty-four years ago, women all around the world couldn't see themselves as Barbie: a stick-thin doll with big-boobs, blonde hair and blue eyes. Three women share whether that's changed for them.

title.children: Barbie went from a stick-thin blonde to saris and nose rings. But has she changed enough?

image.altText: A father holds a baby, as he stands at a window.

items.synopsis: Australian men are reporting high-level loneliness. These experts are trying to understand why, and what can be done to fix the problem.

title.children: Which age group of men are the loneliest? This survey had surprising results

image.altText: A young woman with grey hair and piercing blue-green eyes looks at her reflection in a handheld mirror

items.synopsis: Meet social media's "greyfluencers" — mostly young women who are encouraging others to embrace the beauty of their natural hair colour.

title.children: 'I haven't looked back': Meet the young women ditching hair dye and going grey

image.altText: A protester holds a sign saying 'sacred land' at a Rio Tinto protest.

items.synopsis: Fair Australia has shared a quote from WA Premier Roger Cook saying the state's new Aboriginal cultural heritage laws and the Voice "do the same thing". But the quote was shared out of context.

title.children: CheckMate: Do WA's new Aboriginal cultural heritage laws 'do the same thing' as the Voice?

image.altText: Marketa Vondrousova sinks to her knees on Wimbledon's Centre Court.

items.synopsis: Elina Svitolina's comeback dream is shattered by another on a similar path as Ons Jabeur once again looks for history and Wimbledon final redemption.

title.children: Tennis history guaranteed to be made in Wimbledon ladies' singles final

image.altText: A footballer smiles during training, as her ponytail flies up in the air.

items.synopsis: Australian star Ellie Carpenter says she can't wait to play her Lyon teammates at Docklands tonight, as the Matildas prepare for the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Matildas believe sold-out friendly clash with France is the perfect preparation for Women's World Cup glory

image.altText: a group of politicians pile on and shove eachother in parliament.

items.synopsis: Water is thrown before a brawl erupts between politicians and Kosovo's parliament descends into chaos.

title.children: Brawl breaks out in Kosovo parliament after prime minister is showered with water

image.altText: Emily Blunt with her arm around Cillian Murphy

items.synopsis: Stars including Cillian Murphy and Emily Blunt leave the event once the SAG-AFTRA strike was announced.

title.children: Oppenheimer stars walk out on premiere as Hollywood actors strike

image.altText: Andrew Tate wearing sunglasses walks with brother Tristan

items.synopsis: Andrew Tate, a social media personality known for expressing misogynistic views online, and his brother say the allegations have cost them their freedom and millions in revenue.

title.children: 'Serial liar': Andrew Tate sues woman accusing him of human trafficking

image.altText: A close shot of Philip Lowe wearing a suit against a dark background.

items.synopsis: Reserve Bank of Australia governor Philip Lowe won't be in the top job for much longer, but he hasn't been fired. Here's a quick guide to get you up to speed.

title.children: Why a new RBA governor won't necessarily mean a change to interest rates

image.altText: Commonwealth Bank chief executive Matt Comyn looks at the camera in an office setting.

items.synopsis: Only 60 per cent of the Reserve Bank's increases in the cash rate have been felt by households so far, says CBA boss.

title.children: Young renters under most strain, but full mortgage pain yet to be felt, warns CBA boss

image.altText: A metalic Toyota symbol on a White Toyota Hi-Lux with the defective DPF.

items.synopsis: Toyota has announced a technological breakthrough in batteries, but questions have been raised over the company's dubious EV track record.

title.children: Why some EV drivers are sceptical of Toyota's battery breakthrough

image.altText: A large white space rocket sits on a railway platform, surrounded by forest with some people seen nearby.

items.synopsis: India aims to become just the fourth nation, along with the United States, the former Soviet Union and China, to land spacecraft on the Moon as it tests technology it hopes to use in future interplanetary missions.

title.children: 'A safe and soft landing on lunar surface': India's latest mission to Moon about to blast off

image.altText: A woman hold a ball in the air while looking to pass.

title.children: Super Netball veteran Mentor heading back to England as search for eighth team drags on

image.altText: Southern Queensland vegetable grower Tony Gibb squats in a field of cauliflower in a paddock near Toowoomba, July 2023.

items.synopsis: Tony Gibb employs hundreds of people to help run his farm – but with the climate one of his key challenges, he's also now got a world-leading climate scientist on the books.

title.children: As a possible El Niño looms, what will this mean for the people growing your food?

image.altText: John Kerry with grey hair wearing a royal blue jacket with a purple tie, looking up wiht his hand raised

items.synopsis: John Kerry, the US special envoy on climate change, told a congressional hearing the government would not contribute to a fund to pay countries that have been damaged by climate-driven disasters.

title.children: US will 'under no circumstances' pay climate reparations to developing countries

image.altText: A young Thai man holds up one finger while surrounded by photographers

items.synopsis: The leader of Thailand's pro-reform party has been blocked from taking power. Here's what could happen next.

title.children: Thailand's only candidate for PM was blocked from power. Here's why that could trigger 'an uprising'

image.altText: Russian Major General Ivan Popov in a military uniform.

items.synopsis: Claims a Russian general says he has been dismissed as a commander after telling the military leadership about the dire situation on the frontline in Ukraine.

title.children: Russian general dismissed after accusing top officers of betraying soldiers

image.altText: On the bottom right corner is a stop sign, two lit up red crosses and police officers walking around in front of a big gate.

items.synopsis: A Secret Service report says a thorough FBI analysis of DNA and surveillance footage failed to find who was responsible for the drugs.

title.children: Investigation into White House cocaine fails to identify suspect

image.altText: A sketch showing a side view of a man in a black suit and a judge in red above him on a bench

items.synopsis: The actor told a London court "there was a rush to judgement" and he lost his job and reputation in a matter of days.

title.children: Actor Kevin Spacey says his 'world exploded' following sexual assault allegations

image.altText: Three young men in red and white AFL guernseys yell in front of a big crowd.

image.altText: A boy in a white shirt smiles as he looks over his shoulder at the camera

items.synopsis: A private college in Adelaide's north is fined $420,000 for breaching the Work Health and Safety Act after a teenage student drowned during a 2021 school camping trip.

title.children: Private college fined after teenager's death during school trip

image.altText: A large crowd of African women and children in colourful clothing wait in queues in a sandy desert environment.

items.synopsis: At least 87 people — some of them from the ethnic African Masalit tribe — were killed by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and an affiliated Arab militia, the UN Human Rights Office said.

title.children: Mass grave with at least 87 bodies found in Sudan's volatile Darfur region

image.altText: A woman sits at a table typing on a laptop in front of a white wall. An artwork next to her of an eyeball appears to look at her

items.synopsis: Thousands of Australian public sector staff will be allowed to permanently work from home following a "groundbreaking" union deal — but business lobby groups in one capital city say any move to follow suit at local level would be a "death knell" for CBD retail.

title.children: Work-from-home deal 'groundbreaking', but business groups warn of CBD 'death knell'

image.altText: An indigenous man and woman wearing a red and white football jersey with their hands on their hips.

items.synopsis: From the west coast of the United States, rapper The Kid LAROI is making his mark on his former hometown in outback New South Wales.

title.children: Rapper The Kid LAROI sponsors outback footy club's Indigenous guernsey
